questions.text: The primary structure of a protein refers to _____.

choices.text: Linear structure and order of the amino acids present
Regular conformational forms of a protein
Complete three dimensional structure of the poly peptide units of a given protein

questions.solution:
The primary structure of a protein refers to the linear structure and order of the amino acids present.

There are four known levels of protein structure:

  • Primary: A linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain
  • Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of polypeptides. Eg: Alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends
  • Tertiary: Secondary structures arranged into larger functional units
  • Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides arranged in a spatial manner

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Alpha helix and beta pleated sheet are examples of the ______ structure of a protein.
questions.solution:
Alpha helix and beta-pleated sheets are examples of the secondary structure of a protein.

The secondary structure of a protein refers to the folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of a polypeptide chain. Examples include alpha helix, beta sheets, turns and bends. 

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding alpha helix?

choices.text: Stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from the peptide bond.
A complete turn of an alpha helix contains 3.6 amino acyl residues.
Pitch of the helix is 0.54 nm.
Large numbers of charged amino acids disrupt the helix.

questions.solution:
Alpha helix is stabilized primarily by intra-chain hydrogen bonds. 

Alpha helix is the most common and stable secondary structure of protein. It is a rigid, right-handed spiral. A complete turn of the helix contains an average of 3.6 aminoacyl residues. The rise per turn of the helix (pitch) is 0.54nm. 

Large numbers of charged amino acids (glutamate, aspartate, histidine, lysine, and arginine) disrupt the helix by forming ionic bonds or by electrostatically repelling each other.

questions.text: What is the most common and stable conformation for a polypeptide chain?
questions.solution:
The most common and stable conformation for a polypeptide chain is alpha helix.

The alpha helix has high stability due to the presence of a large number of hydrogen bonds and van der Waals interactions between the amino acids. Hemoglobin and myoglobin are proteins whose major secondary structure is the alpha helix.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids do not participate in the formation of an alpha helix?
questions.solution:
Proline does not participate in the formation of an alpha helix. 

The stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from hydrogen bonds formed between the oxygen of the peptide bond carbonyl and the hydrogen atom of the peptide bond nitrogen of the fourth residue down the polypeptide chain. Since the peptide bond nitrogen of proline lacks a hydrogen atom, it is incapable of forming a hydrogen bond with carbonyl oxygen.

questions.text: All of the following types of interactions cooperate in stabilizing the tertiary structures of globular proteins except _____.
questions.solution:
Peptide bonds are not involved in stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins. It forms the primary structure of proteins.

Interactions stabilizing tertiary structure of proteins are as follows:

  • Hydrophobic interactions
  • Hydrogen bonds
  • Ionic interactions
  • Disulphide bonds

Note:

Hydrogen bonds and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the formation of α helix (secondary structure).

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Proteins are linear polymers of amino acids folded into compact structures. Sometimes, these folded structures associate to form homo- or hetero- dimers. Which of the following terms refers to this associated form?
questions.solution:
Quaternary structure refers to the arrangement of multiple folded polypeptides that aggregate into homo- or hetero-dimers. 

Homo-dimers (e.g., D-amino acid aminotransferase) contain two copies of the same polypeptide chain, while hetero-dimers (e.g., Rab geranylgeranly transferase) contain different polypeptides.

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Which among the following is true about denaturation of proteins?

choices.text: Biological property of the protein is retained.
It mostly renders the protein insoluble.

questions.solution:
Denaturation mostly renders the protein insoluble.

Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures of protein. Thus, the biological property of the protein is lost. However, there is no hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure.  

Denatured proteins are often insoluble and precipitate from the solution. This process may be reversible under ideal conditions, such that the protein refolds into its original structure when the denaturing agent is removed.

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Chaperones assist in protein folding. 

Chaperones are heat shock proteins. They bind to the short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of an extended polypeptide. Thus, they shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating. This provides the polypeptide an opportunity to form an appropriate secondary structure.

When a protein is thermodynamically trapped in a misfolded dead-end form, chaperones can rescue the protein by unfolding their hydrophobic ends. Thus, they provide the protein a second chance to fold productively.

questions.text: All of the following are storage proteins except _____.
questions.solution:
Myoglobin binds oxygen in muscles and is not a storage protein. 

Proteins that act as a storehouse of amino acids and metal ions are called storage proteins. They are as follows:

  • Ferritin
  • Ovalbumin of egg white
  • Glutelin of wheat
  • Gliadin of wheat
  • Vitellin of egg yolk
  • Oryzenin of rice
  • Milk casein

questions.text:
Which of the following is a protein separation technique based on molecular/ ionic charge?

(SDS-PAGE - sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis)
questions.solution:
Ion exchange chromatography is a protein separation technique based on molecular/ ionic charge.

Other techniques based on molecular charge are:

  • Agarose gel electrophoresis
  • Cellulose acetate electrophoresis
  • Isoelectric focusing
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: Which of the following protein separation techniques is based on the molecular size?
questions.solution:
Size-exclusion chromatography is a separation technique that separates solutes on the basis of the molecular size.

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text:
All of the following are methods used to detect the three dimensional structure of proteins except _____.

(NMR - nuclear magnetic resonance)
questions.solution:
Electrophoresis is not used to detect the three-dimensional structure of proteins.

The techniques used to determine the three-dimensional structures of proteins are as follows:

  • X-Ray crystallography
  • NMR spectroscopy
  • Infra-red spectroscopy
  • Polychromatic X-ray crystallography
  • UV light spectroscopy
  • Optical rotatory dispersion
  • Circular dichromism
  • Computer-based modelling
  • Mass spectrometry

questions.text: Rossman fold-associated NADH domain is found in _____.
questions.solution:
Rossmann fold-associated NADH domain is found in lactate dehydrogenase.

Rossmann fold is an N-terminal NAD(P)+ -binding domain. It is seen in:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Malate dehydrogenase
  • D-glycerate dehydrogenase
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • Formate dehydrogenase

questions.text:
All of the following can determine protein structure except _____.

(NMR - nuclear magnetic resonance)
questions.solution:
High-performance liquid chromatography cannot determine protein structure. It is used for separation, purification, and identification of proteins.

Given below are the various methods to determine protein structure:

  • X-Ray crystallography
  • NMR spectroscopy
  • Mass spectrometry
  • Infra-red spectroscopy
  • Polychromatic X-ray crystallography
  • UV light spectroscopy
  • Optical rotatory dispersion
  • Circular dichromism
  • Computer-based modeling

questions.text: Where is quarter-staggered arrangement seen?
questions.solution:
The collagen fibers have a triple-stranded, quarter-staggered arrangement. 

In a collagen fibre, tropocollagen molecules are arranged side-by-side. Each fibril is displaced longitudinally from its neighbour by less than one-quarter of its length. This is known as a "quarter-staggered array". This arrangement helps in mineralization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a protein-misfolding disease?
questions.solution:
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is not a protein misfolding disease.

Ehlers–Danlos syndrome is a group of connective tissue disorders resulting in mobile joints and skin abnormalities.  It is due to mutation in the genes encoding α collagen 1, procollagen N-peptidase and lysyl hydroxylase. 

The following are examples of protein misfolding diseases:

  • Prion disease: Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, scrapie disease of sheep.
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Beta thalassemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a conjugated protein?
questions.solution:
Albumin and globulin are not conjugated proteins

Based on composition, proteins can be classified into:

1. Simple proteins: They contain only amino acids. 

  • Globular: Albumin, Globulin, histones
  • Fibrous: Collagen, Elastin, Fibrin

2. Conjugated proteins: These contain a non-protein part (prosthetic group).

  • Phosphoproteins: Casein, Vitellin
  • Metalloproteins: Hemoglobin, Carbonic anhydrase
  • Glycoproteins: Blood group antigens
  • Nucleoproteins
  • Lipoproteins
  • Mucoproteins

3. Derived proteins: These are degradation products of native proteins. 

  • Primary: Coagulated proteins
  • Secondary: Peptides

questions.text: Which among the following is not a transport protein?
questions.solution:
Insulin is not a transport protein. 

Insulin is a regulatory protein (hormone) secreted by the beta cells of the pancreas. It promotes anabolism. 

The following are examples of transport proteins: 

  • Hemoglobin transports oxygen from the lungs to the capillaries of the tissues. It is found exclusively in red blood cells
  • Myoglobin functions both as a reservoir of oxygen and as an oxygen carrier. It increases the rate of transport of oxygen within the muscle cell. It is present in heart and skeletal muscle
  • Albumin is a plasma protein that transports cations, fatty acids, bilirubin, etc. It also regulates the plasma oncotic pressure.

questions.text: All are true about collagen except that ________

choices.text: It is the most abundant protein in the body.
Type IV collagen is found in basement membrane
Every third amino acid is alanine
Procollagen is formed inside the fibroblast

questions.solution:
Every third amino acid in collagen is glycine. 

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the body. The major collagen in the body is type I, in which every third amino acid is glycine. It is found in noncartilaginous connective tissues, including bone, tendon, skin. Type IV collagen is found in the basement membrane. 

Collagen is synthesized intracelluarly by fibroblasts as a large precursor called procollagen. The procollagen is then cleaved extracellularly by specific peptidases to form tropocollagen.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which among the following will be reduced in a patient with chronic inflammation?
questions.solution:
Transferrin will be reduced in a patient with chronic inflammation as it is a negative acute phase reactant.

Acute-phase reactants are proteins that increase or decrease in levels in response to inflammatory and neoplastic conditions.

Positive acute-phase reactants

Negative acute-phase reactants

C-reactive protein

Haptoglobulin

Fibrinogen

Ceruloplasmin

Alpha 1 antiprotease 

Mannose-binding protein

Complement factors

Ferritin 

Serum amyloid A 

Albumin

Transthyretin

Retinol-binding protein

Transferrin

Antithrombin

Transcortin

Almost all acute-phase reactants are N-linked glycoproteins. Hence, the overall number of these N-glycan oligosaccharide branches markedly increases during acute inflammation, mirroring the increase of the corresponding acute phase reactant proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
Oligosaccharides are present in glycoproteins.

Glycoproteins are proteins that contain oligosaccharide chains covalently bound to amino acids. The oligosaccharide (carbohydrate) is attached to the protein by cotranslational or posttranslational modification. This process is known as glycosylation. Some examples include collagens, mucin, antibodies and hormones like erythropoietin and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

Related Pearl: Glycoprotein and their functions

Functions Glycoproteins
Structural component Collagens
Lubricant and protective Mucins
Transport Transferrin, ceruloplasmin
Immunologic Immunoglobulins, histocompatibility antigens
Hormone Chorionic gonadotropin, TSH
Enzyme eg, alkaline phosphatase
Antifreeze Plasma proteins of cold-water fish
Interact with specific carbohydrates Lectins, selectins
Regulate folding of proteins Calnexin, calreticulin
Haemostasis Specific glycoproteins on the surface membranes of platelets

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents to her gynaecologist for her annual check-up. An ovarian cyst was noted on ultrasound. Histopathology revealed a mucinous cystadenoma. Which test can be used on the sample to detect the presence of mucin?
questions.solution:
Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) reagent helps to detect mucin which is a glycoprotein.

PAS is a staining method used to detect polysaccharides such as glycogen, and mucosubstances such as glycoproteins, glycolipids, and mucins in tissues.

PAS staining can be used to facilitate the diagnosis of several medical conditions:

  • Glycogen storage diseases (versus other storage disorders)
  • Adenocarcinomas, which often secrete neutral mucins
  • Staining of macrophages in Whipple's disease
  • A1-antitrypsin deficiency if periportal liver hepatocytes stain positive

The image shows mucinous cystadenoma in HE (haematoxylin-eosin) stain and a positive PAS reaction.

Related Pearl: Some Important Methods Used to Study Glycoproteins

Method Use
Periodic acid-Schiff stain Detects glycoprotein as pink bands
Mass spectrometry Molecular mass, composition, sequence, and sometimes branching of a glycan chain. can be used for site-specific glycosylation profiling.
NMR spectroscopy To identify specific sugars, their sequence, linkages, and the anomeric nature of glycosidic chain.
Amino acid or cDNA sequencing Determination of amino acid sequence.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: What is the site of synthesis of O–linked glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
O–linked glycoproteins are synthesized in the Golgi apparatus by the sequential transfer of sugars from their nucleotide carriers to the protein.

O-linked glycoproteins are proteins attached to a sugar (eg: N-acetylgalactosamine) through an O-glycosidic linkage between the hydroxyl side chain of serine/threonine and the sugar. Examples of O-linked glycoproteins include mucins, proteoglycans and collagens.

questions.text: What type of glycoprotein is collagen?
questions.solution:
Collagen comes under glycoprotein sub-classes of O-glycosidic linkages.

Glycoproteins can be divided into three main groups:

  • O-linked: They contain an O-glycosidic linkage. Examples include mucin, proteoglycans, collagens, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 
  • N-linked: They contain an N-glycosidic linkage. The types of N-glycosidic linkage include complex, hybrid and high-mannose types. 
  • Glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored (GPI-anchored): Examples include acetylcholinesterase, alkaline phosphatase, decay-accelerating factor, 5′-Nucleotidase, thy-1 antigen and variable surface glycoprotein (Trypanosoma brucei).

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing?
questions.solution:
Type III collagen is involved in wound healing.

Collagen types I and III predominate in the skin and aponeurotic layers. In the early stages of wound healing, type III collagen is synthesized. It is replaced by type I collagen as wound healing progresses. 

The tensile strength of the healing wound is directly proportional to the amount and type of collagen present. During healing, as disorganized collagen is degraded and reformed, covalent cross-links are formed that enhance tensile strength. The maximum strength of the healed wound depends upon the interconnection of collagen subunits. Approximately 80 percent of the original strength of the tissue is obtained by six weeks after surgery. Wounds slowly continue to get stronger but may never achieve 100 percent of their previous strength.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by the lack of a specific lysosomal hydrolase for glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
Lack of a specific lysosomal hydrolase for glycoproteins cause a group of very rare, autosomal recessive genetic diseases called glycoprotein storage diseases (oligosaccharidoses).

Lysosomal acid hydrolases are specific for the removal of the oligosaccharide chains of glycoproteins. They are primarily exoenzymes that remove their respective groups in sequence in the reverse order of their incorporation (“last on, first off”). When one acid hydrolase is deficient, there is accumulation of partially degraded glycoproteins in the lysosomes. This results in oligosaccharidoses. 

Related Pearl: Diseases due to glycoprotein defect

Diseases Defect Characteristics
I-cell disease Mutation in GNPTA gene leading to a deficiency in enzyme UDP-N-acetylglucoseamine-1-phosphotransferase
  • Coarse facial features
  • Corneal erosion
  • Failure to thrive
  • Hepatomegaly
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency, type II Mutations affecting activity of Golgi-located GDP-fucose transporter 
  • Neutrophil rolling
  • Life-threatening, recurrent bacterial infections
  • Psychomotor and mental retardation
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Genetic mutation leading to the inability to synthesize the glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor that binds certain surface proteins to cell membranes.
  • Lysis of red cells
  • Abdominal pain
  • Back pain
  • Esophageal spasms
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Fatigue
  • Progressive chronic renal failure
  • Thrombophilia
  • Bone marrow failure
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Aplastic anemia
Ehlers–Danlos syndrome Deficiency or mutation in Lysyl hydroxylase-1  
  • Neonatal kyphoscoliosis
  • Generalized joint laxity
  • Skin fragility
  • Severe muscle hypotonia at birth
Oligosaccharidoses Lack of a specific lysosomal hydrolase for glycoproteins
  • Delay in intellectual and physical development.
  • Seizure
  • Joint stiffness and pain
  • Problems with vision and hearing
  • Anaemia, nose bleeds, and easy bleeding or bruising
  • Swollen abdomen due to enlarged spleen or liver. 
Congenital disorders of glycosylation   Glycosylation of a variety of tissue proteins and/or lipids is deficient or defective
  • Fatal, malfunction of several different organ systems
Familial tumoral calcinosis (FTC) UDP-GalNAc transferase 3
  • Calcium deposits in skin and subcutaneous tissues
  • Unresponsiveness to parathyroid hormone
Walker–Warburg syndrome (WWS) Defective α-dystroglycan
  • Agenesis of corpus callosum
  • Anal atresia
  • Atresia of the external auditory canal
  • Blindness
  • Buphthalmos
  • Cerebellar dysplasia
  • Cleft upper lip
Hereditary erythroblastic multinuclearity with positive acidified serum lysis test (HEMPAS) Defects in alpha–mannosidase II
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis
  • Haemolysis & erythroblast morphological abnormalities
  • Hypoglycosylation of some red blood cell (RBC) membrane proteins

questions.text: Which of the following disease is associated with defective glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI)?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria results from mutation of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)

GPI is necessary for the attachment of decay-accelerating factor (DAF) (CD55) and CD59 to the RBC membrane. Because of the absence of DAF when GPI is mutated, the complement system attacks the RBCs resulting in hemolysis. Patients present with symptoms of: 

  • Anemia
  • Esophageal spasm
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Abdominal pain
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Treatment is with eculizumab, which is a terminal complement inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Diseases due to glycoprotein defect

  • Life-threatening, recurrent bacterial infections

  • Seizure

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with I-cell disease?
questions.solution:
Buphthalmos is not a feature of I-cell disease.

I-cell disease is an inherited lysosomal storage disorder caused by a defect in the Golgi enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase. This results in failure of the Golgi to phosphorylate mannose residues (↓mannose-6-phosphate) on glycoproteins. Hence, proteins are secreted extracellularly instead of being delivered to lysosomes. Lysosomes lack most normal enzymes and thus accumulate undegraded molecules, forming inclusion bodies. 

It is characterized by the following:

  • Coarse facial features
  • Gingival hyperplasia
  • Clouded corneas
  • Restricted joint movements
  • Claw hand deformities
  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • High plasma levels of lysosomal enzymes

Related Pearl: Diseases due to glycoprotein defect

Diseases Defect Characteristics
I-cell disease Mutation in GNPTA gene leading to a deficiency in enzyme UDP-N-acetylglucoseamine-1-phosphotransferase
  • Coarse facial features
  • Corneal erosion
  • Failure to thrive
  • Hepatomegaly

  • Life-threatening, recurrent bacterial infections
  • Psychomotor and mental retardation

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product?
questions.solution:
When glutamine is replaced by asparagine, there is no change in the function of the protein product.

This is due to the concept of conservative or homologous replacement of amino acids. Asparagine and glutamine are both uncharged polar (hydrophilic) amino acids. Thus, when glutamine is replaced with asparagine there is no change in the polarity or the charge of the peptide/protein.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome?
questions.solution:
The proteasome takes part in protein degradation. 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.

Clinical relevance: It plays an important role in antigen presentation to T lymphocytes as it degrades viruses and other molecules to small peptides.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilised by disulphide bonds
Secondary and tertiary structures depend upon amino acid sequence

questions.solution:
The tertiary structure is three dimensional is the right answer among the given options. 
 
Proteins are structurally organised into four levels, as follows:
  • Primary: The linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain
  • Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of polypeptides. Eg: alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends
  • Tertiary: Secondary structures arranged into larger functional units called domains
  • Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides arranged in a spatial manner

Other options:

Option B: Protein denaturation results in the unfolding and disorganization of the secondary and tertiary structures without the hydrolysis of peptide bonds, which form the primary structure.

Option C: Hydrogen bond and Van der Waal interactions are involved in the stabilization of secondary structure(helix). Disulfide bonds stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins.

Option D: Primary structure depends upon the amino acid sequence, not secondary or tertiary.
